summary: Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) has just finished college and, back at his parents' house, he's trying to avoid the one question everyone keeps asking: What does he want to do with his life? An unexpected diversion crops up when he is seduced by Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), a bored housewife and friend of his parents. But what begins as a fun tryst turns complicated when Benjamin falls for the one woman Mrs. Robinson demanded he stay away from, her daughter, Elaine (Katharine Ross).

reviews.content:
Watched again in April 2023.   Dustin Hoffmann plays a stalker. Katherine Ross plays a co-dependent frat girl. Yeah, Anne Bancroft plays a love-starved, sex-starved middle age rich housewife. Everybody else just simply talks too much.  I honestly got tired of Dustin Hoffman doing nothing, lots of doing nothing. If I were "Elaine", I would have gotten a restraining order.
 
Maybe I liked it in 1967 because everyone raved about it.  I didn't know any better. In 2023 I still probably don't know any better, but I can now say that it is boring and much ado about nothing.    The ending was kinda neat, though.
30% rating ... I thought this was a sub-par coming-of-age film that hasn't aged that well.

The goal of the movie was to show the awkwardness of the main character, so instead it ended up putting him in unrealistic situations, making him look like an idiot, which in turn decreased in the potential ability for it to be enjoyable. The reviews of The Graduate are generally divided between completely favorable or absolutely negative, which means there is a common ground in between where both are right. On the one hand, it's a movie that was ahead of its time, with the acting, cinematography, sentimental elements which were not too common at the time, and even the plot which though it didn't offer much was among the first of its kind. On the other hand, there's slow pacing, and as aforementioned some things are unrealistic and do not make sense, especially in the way the characters act. However, The Graduate is slightly redeemed by its ending, and though maybe not a must-watch, it's still a timeless watch for cinema enthusiasts.

The Graduate works because director Mike Nichols puts emotion front and center. It's a film that must be felt and those feelings of relatable sympathy make it timeless. The film is about a quarter-life crisis. It's the post-college season where a person drifts aimlessly without purpose or direction. Benjamin Braddock is a rudderless boat and his struggle rings true. 

The more I watch The Graduate the more I like it. The film is 50 years old yet every generation there is a new batch of young adults who discover it. Nichols was able to capture that transitional period with raw honesty. Based on the novel by Charles Webb, The Graduate is the perfect marriage between Nichols and Webb. Nichols was an experienced stage director and on his second marriage. At 36, he was the ideal age to reflect on the quarter-life crisis without being too far past it. Webb wrote the book at age 24 shortly after graduating Williams College. 

The character of Ben is based on Webb. Nichols took Webb's story and turned it into cinematic art. It's a modern time capsule of 1967. It reflected and spoke to a generation the way Easy Rider did two years later. The movie only works if Ben is an underdog. Ben wants to be treated like an adult but he is far from ready. But Ben should be careful what he wishes for. Ben's parents parade him around as the golden boy. They are proud of his accomplishment and all their friends want to know what's next. 

Ben feels the weight of this pressure. He just experienced four years of freedom in Mass. and now he's back under his parents' roof. There's a shot where we can see Ben through the fish tank. Ben is drowning, the melancholia is present. When he tries on some scuba gear in a later scene he's underwater again. Ben, however, is about to surface for air. Mrs. Robinson initiates an affair with Ben and treats him like an adult in the process. 

Ben is in a state of depression and apathy and she takes him out of it. She's a sweet, charming, and loving authority that Ben can submit to. This isn't the manic pixie dream girl we see in some movies. This is the seductive mature dream cougar. The relationship is offered as sex without love which becomes a problem for Ben. When Mrs. Robinson first seduces Ben, he is looking at a portrait of Elaine. He then sees an unclothed Mrs. R reflected in the glass frame. Mrs. Robinson is simply a reflection of what Ben wants. Elaine is the real thing. Elaine is who he falls in love with. 

Mike Nichols uses the language of film to tell a story like no one else. The philosophy of classic Hollywood is that the audience should not be aware that they are watching a movie. Stuff like cutting and scene transitions were hidden. But Nichols took a risk with The Graduate and it paid off. He broke the rules. He frequently reminds the audience that they are watching a director with style and vision. He match cuts between the pool and the hotel room. He does establishing shots from a crane with a camera zoom. He puts the camera in voyeuristic places through car windows. He does a long take in the dark with just a visible lamp.

The first line of the film is a pilot saying, "Ladies and gentleman, we are about to begin our decent into Los Angeles." This film is about Benjamin's decent into messy scandal and heartbreak. Is Ben an antihero? He is in the sense that there's a greater villain. Mrs. Robinson is the one cheating and Ben is complicit. The film front loads Ben with sympathy which is the key to the character. Ben is likable and relatable enough for the audience to invest in him and care about the outcome. 

When Ben confesses to Elaine about the affair its painful and devastating. In the foreground Elaine wears a smile that quickly fades. In the background is a rain soaked and crushed Mrs. Robinson. The first half of the film is perfection. It's a whirlwind romance that ends with the inevitable pain of failure. The second half is Ben paying for his sins with suffering. Ben is a deeply flawed character but he's not a static one. He makes different mistakes. 

For Ben, being with Mrs. Robinson represented the adult world. When Ben pursues Elaine it's an overcorrection. Ben moves to Berkley where he apologizes to Elaine and explains that it was Mrs. Robinson who seduced him. Elaine then forgives Ben and considers taking him back. Then all hell breaks loose. Irony is sweet. Mrs. Robinson turned Ben into a person that Elaine would want to date, a confident guy with experience. 

Ben also had social proof on his side from the multiple times the Robinsons and the Braddocks tried to set Elaine and Ben up. At one point, Ben says to Mrs. Robinson "you don't think I'm good enough for your daughter" and he's right. The aimless, sheepish, lost cause Ben isn't good enough. He's a weak man who is made stronger by growing pains. This cause and effect parallels the film's end. It's Ben's fault that Elaine is getting married to Carl Smith, the "make out king." And here's why. The affair between Ben and Mrs. R leads the Robinsons to get a divorce. 

Simply put, Elaine can't go home. Her financial security is gone and she can't stand
her mother. If Elaine drops out of school and marries Carl for financial security then she's repeating the past like her mother did. Ben must try and stop Elaine from making a similar mistake. It's his last shot of redemption. I'm not optimistic about Ben and Elaine's future. I don't think they end up together. But I'm encouraged by Ben's development. Ben fighting off the wedding attendees with a cross is 180 degrees from the Ben we first see. He's a man transformed.

Simon & Garfunkel are my favorite band. The songs created by this folk-rock duo are haunting, stirring, and moving. The combination of Paul Simon songs with Mike Nichols images is truly magnificent. The songs are used very effectively. Nichols often uses the whole song and is fond of repeating songs. The Graduate is one of my favorite films. It's the kind of movie that makes me want to make movies. Mike Nichols is an inspiration. It's the kind of film that opened my eyes to the transcendent journey a film with mature and adult themes could take me on.
One of the top 5 love stories of all time.

WOW! This movie is the closest thing to perfection in the whole cinema history. The movie is a visual gem, Its amazing how a movie made in 1967 is more beautiful than nowadays movies which use newer technology. Here every camera shot is a beauty. The soundtrack is a piece of art. Probably the best combination of music and film, its wonderful. There is no acting. There are just real people living on the screen. Extremely funny, making even the saddest person to laugh.
3 years ago- Strong performances, an unforgettable sound track, and iconic shots and direction work to insure that The Graduate will always be hailed as a classic.
great camera work and editing doesn't save this movie

Well now it's getting too real. But this film is incredibly funny, incredibly well-acted, and holds such a powerful ending that really emphasizes the overall idea of listlessness, distraction, and indulgence that this film is investigating. It holds up so well, and that hedonistic trance he goes through early in the second act--complete with all-time greatest match cuts--is some of the most effective filmmaking I've born witness to. And the soundtrack is still memorable as ever. A timeless classic.
The most overrated movie of all time perhaps? An average looking slow witted young man boned a cougar. Who cares? Dustin Hoffman is overrated as an actor. The only acting he ever did was in RainMan.
One of the most intelligently made movies ever.

Much has been said about how good The Graduate is. I have one word really to say, Amen! This film is wonderful in every way, from the cinematography, to the acting to the soundtrack.

ACTING- The acting is really quite excellent in The Graduate. In his first major role, Dustin Hoffmann(a great actor) is sensational as the innocent college graduate, while Anne Bancroft is also excellent as the older woman who seduces him. And Katherine Ross was surprisingly effective as the daughter Hoffmann's character falls for.

DIRECTION- Mike Nichols' direction is very, very good, easily one of his best directing jobs. He ensures flawlessly that there isn't a single wasted scene while watching The Graduate. And in my opinion, he thoroughly deserved the best director Oscar.

SCREENPLAY- I don't know when to start when saying how good The Graduate's script is. The humour is sophisticated and has the bite of a dry martini.

CINEMATOGRAPHY- The Graduate also benefits hugely from having beautiful cinematography, and it is quite innovative too. It also has a sense of visual irony about it, especially in the scene where Hoffmann runs to the church.

SOUNDTRACK- Maybe I am biased because I am very fond of Simon and Gunfunkel. In The Graduate, the soundtrack is so moving and beautiful, perfectly captures the mood of disaffected youth seething beneath the laid-back exteriors of the 1960s.

STORY- The Graduate works brilliantly as a satire, and the story is never less than engaging and thoughtful.

So all in all, The Graduate is a wonderful film on every level, one of my personal favourites of the 1960s that's for sure. 10/10 Bethany Cox

The Graduate is art.  But like some art - it doesn't always work.  And when you walk away, you shrug your shoulders and wonder what all the fuss was about.  The amazing amount of perfection in this movie is entirely due to the camera shots and acting - they are both iconic.  But the story is line is so bad that you wonder why you are watching it.  Over stereotyping the parents as silly establishment mindset is cheap and almost cartoon like.  Switching the "lost rich kid" main character, Dustin Hoffman, to your basic stalker after one extremely bizarre date for the second half of the movie is creepy and makes no sense.  He is not the person who spent the first half of the movie searching for the meaning of his life, but actually a weird nerdy stalker. And then there is Emily, the object of his so called desire, who falls for this guy after one horrible date wherein she learns he is capable of being hurtful to attain his goal, and then ask for forgiveness.  And on top of that, she finds out he has been shagging her Mother. Why she doesn't run from him and call the police when he follows her to Berkeley, again, makes no sense.  And then of course, there is the Mother, played very deftly by Anne Bancroft.   Also lost in her loveless marriage, she takes on the affair as her escape.  Never mind that it is with the son of her husband's partner in business, and that she lies about it as a "rape" when caught by her family, but again, no one calls the police.  But she at least has the one common decency to set boundaries with Dustin that he cannot date her daughter.  And of course, this idiot doesn't understand why that should be.   Wouldn't that make a lovely Christmas story at the dinner table for everyone to enjoy!  And the final straw of the movie is the strange abrupt ending wherein Dustin Hoffman is sliding back into his lost character on the bus ride after he wins the girls heart and "rescues" her from the life of the establishment at the very alter of her marriage.  Again, the transition makes no sense.  The plot is simply bad.

Artistic cinematically but questionable plot and character wise. The narrative was mostly predictable and repetitive, the ending was very abrupt, and none of the characters were really likeable, with the main character being a desperate stalker, the mum being a liar, the daughter being a directionless idiot, and the parents making an excessive show of everything. However, there was some effective humour, the acting was excellent, the symbolism with the sets/props and lighting was well thought out, and the cinematography, visual effects, and editing were solid. On the other hand, the soundtrack didn't fit that well in my opinion and consisted of the same songs over and over; it would have been better if it had been a score.

Great cinematography, great acting, great writing, great direction and great music choices (wait, didn't I write my L.A. Confidential review like this?), coupled with a thought-provoking, subtly haunting ending make The Graduate a true coming-of-age classic.

This is one of the films that reminds uou of been an teenager and being lost, proncipaly in love, when despite the ods, we give yourselfs to what we believe in and love for, The graduate will me marked in my history.

While certainly an aged movie, you can still see how innovative it was in it's storytelling for the time. Movies like this just weren't getting made before this and it was a definite statement from the perspective of an up and coming generation of Boomers.
Ahead of its time with cinematography and editing, while nothing spectacular in the story department, it's no wonder why it has remained a classic.

Maybe a bit overrated. I can see how non movie buffs would think this movie is better than it really is. Overall not much happens in the movie, just a bunch of spontaneous and unrealistic interactions.
After finishing the movie I was a bit disappointed. The humour was a bit redeeming and Dustin Hoffman carried the movie. I guess I would watch again but definitely don't understand why people consider this a "must see". There are many other classics to watch before you get to this one.

Actively search for reasons to dislike The Graduate, and you will find many. As a coming of age story, Dustin Hoffman's Benjamin sways towards the sort of entitlement and "rich boy boredom" that so often renders a protagonist detestable and requires the film to teach them a lesson in order to emerge with a positive perception. The viewer's frustration begins to mirror that of Ben, but becomes directed towards him rather than his trials. Hoffman plays the role's immaturity giving way to a determined independence marvelously, but does seem too old for his part. Bancroft is quite good as the seductive Mrs. Robinson, whereas Ross struggles a bit towards the end with a lack of emotional depth in her relationship with Ben. The Graduate's flaws also include predictability, as the second half of the film holds no surprises. Some of the filmmaking techniques on display are noticeably stylish and specifically orientated such as its zooms and cuts, although I have not quite decided if these elements provide a tasteless bombardment of style or really poignant signposting. The lighting and general cinematography tends to be a highlight. 

I do find The Graduate riveting despite its flaws. Simon and Garfunkel's music really beds into the film and produces a melancholic atmosphere with slightly sinister undertones, the performances are largely splendid, and if regarded as a critique and satirisation of its privileged protagonist's aimlessness, as there is a substantial case for, it succeeds on the most vital levels.

A humorous and sensitive staging of the indescribable burden that a post-graduate state of confusion is. Make it with a great performance of awkwardness and indecision followed by their contrary substitutions of a gonna-be grown-up by Dustin Hoffman, an inviting sexual uncertainty given by Anne Bancroft, and a set of Simon & Garfunkel songs that will get stuck in your head anew - you have The Graduate!
Every director should study this film.
No no no no. This movie is not good. Irresponsible to give this movie a good review. Too many reviewers have been negligent and reckless when reviewing movies. A wiseman wouldn't watch The Graduate

A movie close to greatness but not quite there because of some imperfections. The first part is memorable in introducing the graduate, overwhelmed by his family's expectations, and Mrs. Robinson, archetype of the "MILF" who plays with the young man and incidentally replaces in him pressure with perdition. The seduction game is brilliant and incredibly fun, but then drama occurs, and this is where it starts to feel less believable. A beautiful but repetitive soundtrack along with some wonky editing contributes to exacerbate the bitter ending that ruins a much awaited final relief.
I'd rate this better but the two songs on repeat kills the mood.
This movie is perfect escapism with maybe the best soundtrack of all times. A fun trip back to the 1960s, as well as a timeless coming of age story.

Mike Nichols' The Graduate, besides being a great movie, also has to be considered one of the most influential films in American cinema.  The Graduate was one of the first American films where people spoke like real people and reacted as real people would react, much like films that followed by the likes of Altman, Ashby and Scorsese.  In addition, Nichols leaned towards longer takes than were used at the time, an example being the Scuba scene early in the film where Dustin Hoffman's character remains submerged in the pool to escape those around him.  The movie itself is fantastic, filled with clever dialogue, subtle humor, stellar performances, and a great soundtrack by Simon and Garfunkel.
This movie is artfully made, but it's almost as if the director is trying to make you feel as suicidal and useless as his main characters. Hello darkness, my old friend. . .

The movie is good on its own merits, but the music is what makes The Graduate valid, important to the times and memorable. Without Simon & Garfunkel, Bancroft & Hoffman were just two good actors playing head games in a forgettable story.
An entreteined, funny and solid classic movie

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #7: I was surprised this film was ranked as high as seventh on this list but I really enjoyed this coming of age dramedy, one that surprised me with a more innocent tone than I expected given the subject matter. The acting felt natural and the dialogue was crisply humorous without sacrificing any emotional weight. The pool scene, which has actually become pretty cliche in movies about teen angst these days, is an example of Nichols ability to create an emotional reaction in me and project the same feeling of dread and anxiety I would imagine Hoffman's character is feeling at that time. The pacing was near perfect as this run time flew by for me, but my one critique, and probably what keeps me from rating this higher, was that I didn't particularly care for the ending, which I felt was rushed and half baked, albeit maybe not out of character. 8.5/10
Must not have aged well as I could barely watch it due to how cringy the behaviour of all characters was.
Timeless. Great performances all around and a memorable soundtrack. Funny, touching, seedy but  transcendent at the end.

The Graduate took comedic filmmaking to a new high, with amazing standout performances, excellent directing, and one of the best written endings a romantic comedy could have. Because of all this, I definitely recommend it for anyone looking for a good laugh and an intriguing study of what lies ahead for the characters after this film.

The film was made 22 years before I was born. And maybe that's why the long, slow montage scenes with a too-often used song just doesn't work for me. It was interesting, I guess. Spoiler alert: But Elaine's willingness to be with Ben is completely ridiculous. Guy never offered her anything. He stalked her. She got over him banging her mom just like that? Maybe in the 60s, things were different. This movie would never get made with the same story today. It's certainly a unique film. But I can't say I would watch it again.

20 year old Benjamin Braddock (Dustin Hoffman) is a recent college graduate with no direction in life when he returns to his parents' home.  He is seduced by an older woman Mrs. Robinson (Anne Brancroft) and then winds up falling in love with her daughter Eleanor (Katharine Ross).  The other main character in this film is Simon & Garfunkel music, including "The Sound of Silence" and "Scarborough Fair."

This was quite a risqué movie back in the 1960s what with a young college graduate having an affair with a much older woman and then falling in love with the woman's daughter.  In this day and age, it is rather tame in terms of plot.  

Having seen this for the first time, I was a little surprised at how they seemed to run out of dialogue and spend half the movie as if it was a collection of music videos.  Not that I am complaining since the Simon and Garfunkel music is incredible.

All three leads do a nice job – Hoffman plays awkward really well.  Bancroft comes across as a lonely woman looking for something in what appears to be a loveless marriage.  You can see why she would seek comfort in the arms of a much younger man.  Ross comes across well although she has the least to do except at the very end of the movie.

The movie is good.  The dialogue is witty, but as I mentioned before it seems like they had to supplement the story with lots of musical interludes.  They probably should have beefed up the plots or extended the conversations.  It does surprise me that this is in the top 10 of all movies of all time.  Definitely worth watching if you have never seen it, but this won't leave you amazed.
Loved it for quite a few years, but showing its age.
Uncomfortable but the acting is great.
a classic, nice shots, nice music, grat movie

Benjamin Braddock is a successful guy who just finished all 4 years of college, but what will he do in the real world? The Graduate is a smart film about trying to grow up and figuring out what to do in the world that seems so big.

I was 16 when my parents went to this movie in the theater. I'll never forget my mother's reaction to it. When they got home they were arguing with each other (a common occurence in our house). She was offended and disgusted by the Ann Bancroft character's unapologetic sexuality. She always had a problem with sex and Mrs. Robinson forced her to confront her own sexual inadequacy. She was a product of the peculiar and hypocritical (and catholic)  1950's "moral" value system in which "good" women thought sex was dirty and only a certain "kind" of woman enjoyed it. This cultural indoctrination, I believe, destroyed her life. I saw "The Graduate" much later and immediately understood why my mother hated it. I loved it.
The acting from Hoffman is off the charts. Cracking tale, loved every second of this perfectly pitched film. The soundtrack too is about as good as it gets.
Though satirical in tone for most of its runtime, good cinematography and accurate portrayal by Hoffman tell a deep story about entering adulthood, even if irresponsible.

Good music and interesting direction are not good enough for a decent movie. The young characters are clueless, and Mrs Robinson is somehow sold as a villain. I can see the appeal of the idea that a dork can have an affair with a sexy woman. Maybe you could sell this silly story in the 60s.

I couldn't even finish this movie, it was so bad. I was more bored with Ben's (that was his name, right? Or was it Brad?) life than he was, and that's saying a lot. Oh woe is me. I am a college grad worried about my future. I am also white, wealthy, and a MILF is into me. Heavens, what could possibly go wrong. YAWN. I did not need to see this movie to know this bro would continue winning at life. I don't see any reason for a POC to watch this unless you're some kind of masochist, I guess. If you like white privilege being rubbed in your face, by all means watch this movie to get your fix. I was disappointed with the MILF. Girl, you could've done way better than this trash.

The flawless soundtrack is unforgettable, Dustin Hoffman proves he can act with the big ones since his career's beginning, holding on tight with Anne Brancoft (Terrific as "villain") and the rest of the cast. The story is a little bit of weird for nowadays, but maybe it was revolutionary at the time, still is a very funny movie of its own, with a lot of comedic situations.
Funny, well rounded, until 60 minutes, when things get awkward, characters and story get far too shallow and the last scene is shockingly bad.

A witty and awkward comedy about finding what to do with life. Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft, and Katharine Ross all give great performances. And of course that Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack is amazing!!

An absolute classic. This is clearly one of the all time great movies. It's completely entertaining, a classic soundtrack, it's over 50 years old and still feels fresh. If you haven't seen it and like movies even a little bit you owe it to yourself to give it a watch.
Great movie but not really a comedy...
Funny, Dramatic, And Memorable.
Well-directed and acted, Mike Nichols' The Graduate is an ingenious piece of filmmaking

The Graduate is a fun ride. The story itself is nothing special, but its presentation is. The acting, editing, soundtrack, and pacing are all beautiful. The movie has of the best and most iconic endings ever. 

Ben as a character has a very exponential growth. He starts as the most awkward man alive and quickly gets more and more bold. The entire time he's searching for something to fill a void in his life. Ben's final lash out ends in a satisfying yet aimless moment of catharsis.

The Graduate is a tale of two stories for me, the first half had me glued to the screen and I enjoyed every second of it. The second half dived deep into a love story that I just didn't buy. I was still highly invested in the story but was scratching my head a little at a few decisions made. Everything seemed to happen too fast and It became somewhat implausible. Still it was always entertaining and I will definitely rewatch and add it to my collection!
im crying bcs of maria subira
Horrible Movie, Horrible Writing, Horrible Plot, besides that it was just horrible.
You do not want to miss this movie

A wonderful film about existential post graduation identity crisis, led by an perfectly and inexorably awkward performance by Dustin Hoffman playing the type of character we all know, may have met, may even have been sometimes or for some reasons, but that is rarely committed to film with such fervour and knowing and dedication; the little noises and line readings, the evolution, the angst and the depression are all in his eyes and his mannerisms. 
And if that wasn't enough to make the film so watchable and so funny and rife with pathos, Mike Nichols is the kind of Director from a school and a time when the work could be analysed completely; every frame and every move and every decision means something so simple and so powerful that it's a joy to watch all the way to the iconic and painful and sympathetic ending.
It's brilliantly directed but by the final act it becomes hyperbolic, with a lead protagonist that becomes increasingly harder to like.

Although The Graduate is known to be a classic film about a man being in a relationship with a married woman while talking to the woman's daughter, I found the movie to be a little slow and boring because it lacked excitment and drama until the end of the movie. It was also weird to watch how stalkerish Ben kind of was throughout the movie.
The soundtrack is perfect for the Graduate
One of the best films of all time. Excellent acting and direction.

Here are the problems I personally have with this movie:
1. First the movie tries to establish a reletable character by talking about the pressure he is put on. Then he liberates himself, but because that liberation means acting dumb and stalking, he loses all relatabilty.
2. Most people on this movie happen to be weird, which leaves the movie with a total of 0 likeable characters.
3. The progression of this movie is obvious from the first hint.
4. Some of the comedic moments don't land.
5. Kinda romanticizes stalking and undermines harassement towards men.
Iconic movie, the ending is something fantastic!

I watched it for the first time with great anticipation; I am shocked that this film is considered a classic of cinematic history.  

The musical score is great, as is Anne Bancroft's performance as Mrs. Robinson.  There are also a few good dryly comedic moments between Bancroft and Hoffman juxtaposed quite nicely against the sudden but slow eruption of emotion in a sea of solemnity when the issue first surfaces of a potential relationship between Elizabeth Robinson and Benjamin -- triggering Mrs. Robinson's seething insecurity-fueled anger.

However, there is absolutely no discernible depth of relationship at all between Elizabeth Robinson and The Graduate, who have one tumultuous date, that provides any foundation for a believable expression of love between the two to sustain the premise of the rest of the movie.  That being the case, however, it makes some sense of the attenuated, uncomfortable, joyless ending where it seems to be sinking in that the pair may not have accomplished anything worthwhile after all.

Overall, the language of the script and scenes between Benjamin and Elizabeth seem to be so ridiculously childish a stumbling toward a marriage proposal of sorts, that in addition to being utterly lacking in credibility it reminds one of Hoffman's later flat performance as an idiot savant in Rain Man; this time in co-ed stereo.  

Bottom line:  A great musical score cannot save a sound premise unsupported by an utterly believable script and robotic, shallow relationships between between Benjamin and every other character in the story.

The Graduate is an amazing movie . 

buts its not really pg
Great film although hoffman is far too old to play a teenager.

Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft and Katharine Ross star in Mike Nichols' landmark movie of the late 1960s based on Charles Webb's novel perfectly adapted for the silver screen by Buck Henry (who plays a desk clerk) and Calder Willingham. Hoffman rises to stardom as an ultra-naive college graduate, who has a sexual fling with his neighbor's wife (Bancroft), and then later, he falls in love with her daughter (Ross). Featuring Simon and Garfunkel's delightfully immortal musical score and songs, "Here's to You, Mrs. Robinson" and "The Sound of Silence". Mike Nichols won the Academy Award as Best Director.  Also starring Murray Hamilton, Elizabeth Wilson, Walter Brooke, Alice Ghostley, Norman Fell, William Daniels, Brian Avery, Marion Lorne, Elisabeth Fraser, Richard Dreyfuss & Harry Holcombe.
I've seen movie several times. I detest romantic comedies but this movie is an exception great movie love it!

takes some unpacking. stream of consciousness go: relatable as a current graduate without a real foreseeable future yet. dreams on horizon yet not even close to being realized. scared of just ending up like everyone else. deeper movie than what appears on the surface. also seems all hearty but actually feels really deeply existential and sad. we do not actually have a purpose. we won’t eventually have one. we just... are here. just chase after things here and there. but the ending was quite moving. such amazing actors. dustin hoffman. the looks they gave at the end. confidence and fear at escaping the arranged marriage. perhaps a glint of hope, who knows. at it not being to late for any of us. we still can have dreams for a future. but there isn’t a resolution. we’re not sure what’s next. as is life. also saw my familiar places of LA VERNE and SATHER GATE at berkeley. serendipitous with my time in life. also the camera in perspective from dustin’s character was often quite hilarious but also effective in showing viewpoint of this naive, innocent young man

(Not a full review)

The Graduate is a 1967 comedy-drama directed by Mike Nicholls. The film stars Dustin Hoffman as Benjamin Braddock and Anne Bancroft as Mrs. Robinson.

Great acting, really strong cinematography, good comedy, and a great soundtrack.

Over all I give it a
8/10
Somehow very relatable

How this movie is considered a classic is beyond me. To start, the main character is awful in so many ways. At the beginning of the movie he's painfully awkward to the point that his initial affair is completely unbelievable. In the second half of the movie he's essentially a socially awkward stalker. Neither version of this character is entertaining to watch. (Spoilers ahead, but don't worry, if it keeps you from watching the movie I'm doing you a GIANT favor) After a long affair with Mrs. Robinson he then falls in love with her daughter after one(!) date before she finds out that he's sleeping with her mom. We're then supposed to believe that after he stalks her when she travels back to college (and is also told by her mother that he raped her) that she's going to fall in love with him and wants to marry him?? Come oooooooon 🙄 

The dialogue was also piss poor and instead of giving us conversation that could have enhanced the story and created more meaningful / believable relationships between each of the characters we were stuck listening to Simon & Garfunkel tunes for half the movie. 

I could keep going but I'm so depressed that I wasted two hours of my life on this turd that I no longer want to think about it. This movie sucks HARD. I've seen better Netflix originals than this pile of horse shit 👎🏻

This is one of the few very mainstream films from 1967 that is completely worth viewing today. The cinematography, writing, direction, music and the capturing of a place and a time is superb. Anne Bancroft as the iconic Mrs. Robinson is so memorable that the term has become used in pop culture to refer to any predatory cougar. The coming of age element of the film has been equally influential as Benjamin's ennui and loss of innocence has clearly influenced most future films in the genre. I was expecting it to feel dated and for the material to have been shocking at the time but tame by today's standards but no, even on TV 3 at ten o'clock at night this film plays to a wide audience.

Benjamin Braddock, Dustin Hoffman, was a successful track athlete at University and has recently completed his degree when we first meet him. He has returned to his hometown and experiences increasing pressure from those around him to conform to a lifestyle he may not want. One night the wife of his father's colleague Mrs. Robinson, Anne Bancroft, gets him to drive her home and famously attempts to seduce him. A few nights later he succumbs to her charms and they begin a clandestine affair. The relationship becomes more complicated when he begins a relationship Mrs. Robinson's daughter Elaine, Katharine Ross, but Mrs. Robinson sabotages their relationship and pushes Benjamin away from the family.

So many iconic scenes appear in this film from the scuba diving to the seduction to the final scene on the bus. These are all rightfully iconic because there is something special to all of them as one conveys fear and anxiety, awkward sexuality and the nervousness of an unknown future. You feel all of the emotions that Benjamin feels so strongly in this scene as Nichols is able to create a feeling of claustrophobia and also a funny but still sexually titillating moment in which Bancroft's nude breasts flash across Hoffman's shocked face. As a teenager I feel very nervous about my future and although I doubt I will look to one of my father's colleagues to aid me in my coming of age I am aware I will make stupid, irrational decisions as I leave university.

The performances are all pretty great, although I don't understand Ross's Best Supporting Actress nomination, but Hoffman and Bancroft are the clear standouts. Hoffman being nervous and weird is incredibly entertaining and his use of blank expressions to convey just how confounded Benjamin is works brilliantly. Bancroft's performance unfortunately overshadowed the other great performances she gave, check out The Pumpkin Eater (1964) and The Turning Point (1977), but this is not for no reason because she completely inhabits her role in this. Her authoritative, almost bitchy style of conversing with people leaves you with no doubt that she commands everyone else around her with little trouble and yet towards the end of the film we understand just how sad she is as a human being. Bancroft is obviously sexy but she can be one of the most intimidating forces on any screen when she wants to and we feel Benjamin's fear when she yells "It's too late!"

The final absolutely iconic thing I am going to remark upon is the use of the Simon and Garfunkel soundtrack. Playing "The Sound of Silence" over Benjamin's blank and despondent face sends a stronger message than any dialogue could and the songs are meaningful and well placed in addition to be entertaining and catchy. "Mrs. Robinson" and "April Come She Will" are exquisite and you sometimes feel torn between appreciating the visuals or the audio.

This is ranked 17th on the AFI's 100 Yearsâ¦100 Movies List and although I am slightly surprised they didn't pick more â~serious' fare I am glad that this excellent film receives the recognition it deserves. Bancroft lost the Academy Award for Best Actress to Katharine Hepburn for Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967) which is an absolute crime and we can only be glad that Bancroft won for the great but less brilliant The Miracle Worker (1962). You really must watch this film because it is both important and very watchable.

And here's to you, Mike Nichols, for directing what remains one of the most resonate comedies in cinema, a film that simultaneously captures the ennui and dissonance of its era yet remains timeless and personal across generations, speaking both to the confusion of disaffected youth and to that same feeling among dismayed parents. Teetering between the listless lyricism of the Summer of Love and the outright tumult of the following year, the combination of Simon & Garfunkel's poetic harmonies with Buck Henry's acerbic wit create a dizzying, dazzling affect of hopeless yearning to match the intimate-yet-claustrophobic camerawork. It is a simple story filled with complex characters, both tremendously beautiful and bawdily taboo, a study in contradictions that seeks no easy resolution. If only Benjamin (and apparently Hoffman) weren't such a complete creep, though I suppose that sort of entitled disenchantment among young white men is just as true today as it was in the late Sixties, too.

"And here's to you Mrs. Robinson, your movie's aged but your sex appeal goes on." The Graduate was released more than 50 years ago, and its themes of disillusionment with post-college life and struggling to find your place in the world are still as relevant as ever. Its most quotable line is uttered in the first 20 minutes, and the best scenes almost all occur in the first half. Dustin Hoffman is perfectly cast as the awkward young adult at a crossroads, as in Anne Bancroft as the zesty older woman whose life is far less glamorous than our hero initially thinks. The romance between them is far more convincing than the one between Hoffman and Ross, mainly because I could see what those 2 saw in each other. The 3rd act is where things fall apart, as the film goes from being a satire on love and fulfilment and becomes a creepy melodrama centred around a deranged stalker. The lead start off likeable and innocent but ends up being only a few steps away from being a psycho killer. He acts as though he deserves Ross's character and is content to follow and harass her until she changes her mind. It makes him come across as seriously detestable, and I had no desire to see things work out for him. Also, while the soundtrack might feature the legendary duo of Simon and Garfunkel, only a few of their songs are featured, and some are played up to 3 times, making it feel like the film is often struggling for something to fill the gaps. If it had managed to sustain the quality of the first half into the second, I would highly recommend it. But as is, I'm glad I saw such a talked-about and influential picture, I was just so frustrated at how much better it could, and should, have been.

Nichols's compelling drama of a rift between sexuality and morality is a forward pass on terms of the genre the cinema can and ought to offer. As much as general and diverse the message grows socially, the real raunchy methods up-taken by the writers is bold and vivid enough to leave a long lasting impression. Sweeping of all the perspective, opinions, schemes and what not sort of drama, within around 100 minutes, the anticipated intentions are circled up with an adequate storytelling. If its first act seems humorous and light enough to nail any sort of intensity on the board, the second act adds plethora of spice to the tale with jealousy, politics and selfishness that shows the three dimensional side of these perfectly cooked characters.

And with a jarring last act that gives you goosebumps for its potential to shift the entire tone into an electrifying love story that corners our protagonist to succeed against all odds, the finesse is to aspire from. The nail biting climatic act offers this ethically complex situation a cathartic release which no matter how much crowd pleasing it may seem, is also wisely crafted to be mature. Hoffman as the obedient student and of like-able persona has a completely different identity hidden behind him.

Frankly this is not a pleasant figure and Nichols makes sure he never tries to justify it which would be uncalled for. But justice is to be served, and serving it with an intention to draw out a cinematic arc for the character, there resides a quote that cannot define it all more than enough, "I'll give you 20 dollars for a dime." says Hoffman in his lowest pit. Bancroft and Ross, possibly the combination of the most bizarre triangle love story are holding onto their parts dearly. The Graduate not only qualifies but is undoubtedly a top contender.
As far as 'coming of age' films go this is the pinnacle of said films. 'The Graduate leaves viewers just as unsettled and contemplating life so to speak just like the characters in the film.

This was definitely an interesting drama that touches on a lot of different issues. Crying wolf in rape culture, manipulation within relationships, control and dominance by authority, and the anxiety that comes with being young and inexperienced. Mrs. Robinson is obviously trying to drown out her worries rather than face them, and knows exactly what strings to pull to get her way. She needs therapy, but instead she self-medicates with booze and a boytoy. Though Ben is an adult, he is still easily swayed and malleable to her whims, which ends up costing him down the road. Some might find Ben's obsession in the realm of stalking, but it's also of note that he is someone with a reputation that has been tarnished by hearsay and needs to have it righted not only to clear his own self-perception, but so that he can pursue who he truly loves. The end scene is also iconic and often talked about because even though they have made a big decision and know it was the right thing to do, they still are young and really are scared for the future. When it comes to being a married couple, this is something you face dead in the eyes every day. You don't know how to be the breadwinner, the homemaker, the mother, the father, the leader, sometimes not even the diplomat or how to be the mature one, and you still need to smile together and get on the bus of life where it takes you, knowing everything will be alright down the road. Great film, I can see why it won for best director.

Brilliant comedy/drama about a college graduate (Dustin Hoffman) who becomes seduced by an older, more experienced, and married woman. Complicating matters further, he falls for her daughter. Soundtrack by Simon & Garfunkel features recordings that also compliment the action.

A timeless classic. 

Most men who have seen this film find the affair unreal when young, with Mrs Robinson "old" ( even though Bancroft was only 35 at the time), and then more interesting as they get older. 

Hoffman plays an awkward young man to the hilt. 

While the film captures the period, it is timeless in capturing youthful uncertainty.

I can definitely empathize with what Ben is feeling at the party. I would hate to be in that situation. A graduation celebration party thrown for you but instead of your friends, you're surrounded by your parents friends. My only thought would be, I need to escape right now. I love the handheld camera work during party. It definitely gives off that feeling of anxiety which compliments what Ben is feeling. 

You can tell Mrs. Robinson is experienced, a veteran pro. She knows exactly what she's doing, the way she seduces Ben to do what she wants. It's so twisted to think that Mrs. Robinson would've had sex with Ben on her daughter's bed. Like wtf?! That's like such a power move. It's almost like her saying, "Never mind Elaine, because when I'm through with you, you're only going to be thinking about me". There's obviously some marital problems between Mrs. Robinson and Mr. Robinson - they don't have sex as they don't sleep in the same bed. This explains why she's so eager on having sex with Ben. And poor inexperienced naive Benjamin seems to be a friendless virgin.

Dustin Hoffman's comedic brilliance really shines. All his different mannerisms and little sounds he makes when he gets nervous. Anne Bancroft looks smoking in this movie. I love the highlights and the way she styles her hair. She makes for a very believable cougar who is out for some long overdue sex. What we witness in this movie is a boy's journey into becoming a man and feeling love for the first time. Not only with the loss of his virginity, but also the events that take place after with Elaine and her parents. I love how determined Ben is at the end when he's trying to find and save Elaine.

There's really good moments of dramatic tension throughout that are real attention grabbers. Such an iconic and legendary movie. I'd definitely watch it again and I'm totally buying it on Criterion.

The Graduate is one of those classic films that puzzles me on why it is a classic. I suppose part of it might be a generational thing, but the plot doesn't really speak to me as someone who was born almost 10 years after it came out. For one thing Ben Braddock isn't a likable character, and he continually makes horrid decisions. I get frustrated with him instead of empathizing with him. Dustin Hoffman does well at playing the confused and aimless young man, but when he transitions into obsessive stalker mode I can't stand him. Anne Bancroft is supremely charming as the seductive Mrs. Robinson and she seems to be the only person in the movie with a brain. At every turn she is surrounded by clueless morons, and yet she knows everything that is happening (and often what will happen in the future.) I almost pity her more than anyone else in the film even though she's supposed to be sort of a villain. There's so much in The Graduate that I struggle identifying with, and not much of the humor is effective for me. I think I can see the elements that work for others, but the fact that it is a cultural touchpoint seems strange to me. It's a very straightforward plot that doesn't surprise all that much, and I struggle to find a single character I care about through the whole thing.

The Graduate is directed by Mike Nichols, and it stars Dustin Hoffman in his first main role and Anne Bancroft in a dramedy about a grad student that has no idea about what his future is, until he come across his father's business wife who wants him to take a ride back home, where he seduces him there. When I was at my friend's house, I was looking through his films, and I felt that I wanted to watch Final Fantasy: The Spirits Awaken until my friend comes back as he bought even more movies. However, there were some distractions that didn't got me to see it, and for the movies my friend bought, we decided to watch a movie that he bought, and that was this one, which I'm glad that I finally got to see it as I heard that it's a classic movie, and it really is. I wouldn't really know what the 60s was like since I wasn't born in that time and I haven't watch much films that were around that time either, I'll just put that out there, but it seems like the movie brings the vision about a serious subject that was probably not familiar in that time, and that is cougar. The way that it was talking about really seem to be realistic, and really ahead of its time, like almost the rest of the movie. Even at his first main role, Dustin Hoffman is terrific in this, he's got the charms, and the comedic timing that got me laughing in some scenes. Anne Bancroft plays a seducing character very well that it makes sense why Dustin Hoffman's character would be intimidated by her. The songs are surprisingly catchy to this day, which I didn't know that Sound of Silence by Simon and Garfunkel was in this, and the writing by Calder Willingham and Buck Henry is very well written that it created memorable characters that have to deal with legitimate problems. Even though there are some funny stuff in here, the movie does take itself seriously, and it's executed very well, although some people might find Dustin Hoffman's character a little creepy when it was getting to the end. When it gets to the end of the film, it leads up to one of the funniest parts of the movie, and gets to a resolution that I'm not quite sure whether it's a happy ending or not. I was getting a little bothered by the fact that it was getting a little too long in getting to the destination, but then I thought about it, and realize that it made it look more realistic that it does take some time getting there. In the end, The Graduate is a terrific movie that I'm surprised it took me so long to finally get to watch it.

The Graduate is one of those films that is both dated and timeless at the same time. It was written for the rebellious teens and college students of the time, but still has a lot of universal forces driving the plot. Ben is our anti-hero who is the tortured soul that has no idea how to live his life. All he knows is that he is constantly under the thumb of his parents and their friends. His affair with Mrs. Robinson, his eloping with Elaine, and the way he spends his spare time all revolve around a deep need to satisfy them. Him and Mrs. Robinson make the movie stand out, as they are easily character staples in cinema while the other characters aren't nearly as developed. Just goes to show that you don't have to have a star-studded involved cast to make a pertinent film. A personal theory I have about The Graduate is that Mrs. Robinson's affair with Ben was her way of keeping him from marrying Elaine, in her insane drive to be over protective. She nearly succeeds until they run from the church away from her. There is much debate about the ending of the film, the long bus ride with the altering faces and the Simon and Garfunkel pop song "Sound of Silence". Think of it this way, these two newly grads have never lived a life outside their family, and now they are at a state where they can't come back to them. A dark aspect to this coming of age tale, but it takes a turn to discuss the destruction of the family structure long before it was the norm to do so. It's hard to find anything wrong with a film that does so well at a subtle pushing of the envelope as this one does.

It has such a perfect and controlled balance between light hearted nuanced non-verbal comedy in some of the greatest scenes of this fine picture and also does it create some deeply disturbing situations in some of the low-points of the film, which is a very difficult thing to do, but masterful director Nichols succeeds in every which way along side a career-launching and defining performance by Hoffman as disillusioned college graduate Benjamin Braddock.
This movie not only spawned the great career of Hoffman, it also created the most beloved songs written and performed by the great Simon & Garfunkel (e.g Sound of Silence, Mrs. Robinson, Bridge over Troubled Waters)
This is one hell of a movie that needs to be experienced by everyone.

The Graduate is one of the greatest romcoms ever and one of the first big indie arthouse films. It is truly spectacular, with a compelling story going in all sorts of directions with amazing performances and characters - the film takes an unpredictable and entertainingly real path with its amusing main character.
Ben, a recent college graduate, is caught up in a regrettable affair with his middle aged neighbor Mrs. Robinson, making the affair a guilt trip when he favors her daughter Elaine over her and begins to fall madly for her. Truths unravel, relationships fall apart, and Ben is left questioning his future ultimately not just in careers but in love.
The Graduate is spectacular and a classic romcom. Hoffman is spectacular and amazingly real in his main character role as well as Ross. Mrs. Robinson from start to finish grows more despicable and hateful. The film's story goes in many different and unpredictable directions, giving the ending a surprise of sorts for the audience to root for Ben all the way. Many note its amazingly done soundtrack by Simon and Garfunkel, which fits the mood of scenes very nicely. The Graduate is a pioneer of its genre and is ultimately one of the best of not just its kind but one of the best of the 1960s and of all time.

For those who do not know much about this 1967 flick, here is an introduction. The Graduate is an American comedy-drama directed by Mike Nichols. It traces the journey of a 20 something college graduate Benjamin, who in a period of depression about his future, is seduced by his father's law partner's wife Mrs Robinson and then goes on to fall in love with her daughter Elaine.

The movie was something of a blockbuster at the time of release, with cine-goers identifying with the character of Benjamin and his confused mind. The movie also found appreciation from critics with noted critic Roger Ebert calling it the "most funny movie I has seen in ages". Over the years, the movie has grown in stature and is now regarded as one of the most influential movies of the "Roaring 60s" and a cult classic. It was selected to preserved in 1996 in the United States National Film Registry for being "culturally, historically or aesthetically significant". It is regularly featured in greatest movie lists including the American Film Institute's Top 100 movies and the Empire magazine's Top 500 movies.

Now, with all this praise showered on this film, and me personally being a fan of Dustin Hoffman after watching Straw Dogs and Rain Man, I was naturally inclined to watch this movie. Add to all this, the impact of this movie in pop culture. To quote an example, in "500 Days Of Summer", a movie I loved, a critical plot turn occurs after both leads watch The Graduate and one of them is significantly moved by the movie while the other isn't. All this got me intrigued and I was pretty excited when I got to watch it yesterday!

AND I WAS DISAPPOINTED.

To my understanding, there is no definite plot; much like the Benjamin state of mind, the movie appears confused. Characters come and go, affairs start and end, and you never know. Even the lead characters are poorly written, with none them having emotional heft. You don't identify with them, neither do you feel for them. I watch Benjamin (Dustin Hoffman) for close to two hours and I don't know what kind of person he is; I am as confused as he is. Anne Bancroft playing Mrs Robinson does a good job as a cold manipulative creep, but the weak writing suffocates her. Same goes with Hoffman. A bunch of talented actors are cowed down by the writing.

Elaine Robinson, played by the beautiful Katherine Ross, brings nothing new to the table. The same old "Damsel In Distress" story. Even characters so simple as that of Benjamin's parents was messed up. They seemed invisible while being visible. Creepy!

Choppy editing made matters worse and I wasn't impressed with the cinematography too.

Now to the good stuff, though there aren't many. The performances, to begin with. Dustin Hoffman gives an excellent performance as a graduate with confusion and uncertainty surrounding his future. His vulnerability is well portrayed, despite the weak writing. Same goes with Anne Bancroft. She excels as the manipulative Mrs Robinson who is unafraid to demand what she wants. "An insufferable creep", as Ebert called her. There are some genuine moments of comedy too in the film, one particularly being when Mrs Robinson attempts to seduce Benjamin. It was hilarious. But such scenes are few and far between.

The music was impressive too, though I thought it was a bit overdone. But what I loved most was the last few seconds of the film (which I will not reveal). It points towards an uncertain future despite a happy ending.

Unfortunately, the movie as a whole failed to impress, and if you ask me, give it a miss. You won't regret it.

I always say that a good movie will emotionally connect with you and you will respond to it. But THE GRADUATE failed, and failed miserably.
crap then, '67; crap now, '15

â??This is Benjamin. Heâ??s a little worried about his future.â??
 
No matter what age you are in life, this would have been a sentiment plaguing your mind for the future is unpredictable. What happens when you finish studying? Are you going to start working immediately? Are you happy with that job? Or is this not the right future for me? What do I do? Mike Nicholsâ?? The Graduate may revolve around the uncertainty of graduating childhood, but boy does it get to grips with adulthood, as this film for many people is their first sexual fantasy. The Graduate decides to take that young man worried about his future, and transform that worry into pleasure as Benjamin sexually wanders into the Robinson family.
 
The Graduate tells the tale of a recent college graduate named Benjamin Braddock, who has no well-defined aim in life. This open ended storyline entitles the film to go down any road it desires for Benjamin needs to become enlightened to his lifeâ??s calling. The scriptâ??s ingenuity is that no one would have expected Benjamin to be seduced by a middle-aged, married woman named Mrs Robinson, and then proceed to fall in love with her daughter Elaine. The Graduateâ??s combination of a young manâ??s sexual and emotional escapades within the same family is bound to cause fireworks, for The Graduateâ??s reputation has stemmed from its dramatic sexualisation of a down-to-earth coming-of-age story.
 
Weirdly, The Graduate is considered one of the funniest American films of all time. I find it hard to consider The Graduate a comedy, as its sexually stimulated storyline appears more as a drama. It in no way can be considered a comedy because if you classify a post-studying-life crisis resulting in a sexual affair with a married, alcoholic woman, and then her child, then the comedy genre it seems knows no boundaries and can be anything. The Graduate may force a giggle on a few occasions but the film features far more of other genres to be classified as a comedy. It is more of a combination of eroticism and drama, or better yet an erotic drama that shows Fifty Shades of Grey how to be sexual, yet meaningful in its depictions. From the inceptive seduction of Benjamin at Mrs Robinsonâ??s home, to their inhabitation of hotel after hotel, this sexual affair is your typical affair in todayâ??s world, but back then this was adulterously spicy, and that is the essence of what made The Graduate so special. The famous scene where Bancroft places just her leg in the shot and puts on tights ever so sensually with a hapless Hoffman in the background aroused into paralysis, just like anyone watching, is so masterfully executed. Benjamin then moves onto Elaine, but this relationship is far more emotional than salacious providing a layer of drama to the eroticism. But, like the sensuality, the matriarch of the Robinsons pretty much causes drama whenever she is on screen. Without Mrs Robinson, Iâ??m afraid The Graduate would lose all its charm for her personality is histrionic, her age difference to Benjaminâ??s is scandalous and the way she develops from the seductive temptress into a Havisham-like brute has melodrama written all over it!
 
Anne Bancroft portrays the famous Mrs Robinson with such gravitas that The Graduate belongs to her. She will literally blow you away by her authoritative stubbornness and sexual prowess, which never fails to get her what she wants. She has such a powerfully resplendent aura that her performance fits the symbol of a middle-aged cougar so impressively. The lack of a first name shoots Mrs Robinsonâ??s appeal sky-high for her mysteriousness makes her seductively alluring. Dustin Hoffman stars as Benjamin Braddock, marking his first foray into acting. Braddock is such a creepy character as he for the first hour is almost paralysed in the same position, facially and physically. Hoffman captures the character so well because he has that underdog charisma to pull off being silently innocent for most of the film. He is so visibly discontent with life that Hoffmanâ??s awkwardly numb face fits the profile so well. Katharine Ross is Elaine Robinson, Benjaminâ??s love interest. Ross may be the daughter in the family, and only nine years younger than Bancroft, but boy does Bancroft out-sex her daughter and become the fascination of many men.
 
These three actors are lucky, lucky people, for the amount of past and future Hollywood legends that were considered for or who wanted the roles is ridiculous. For the part of Mrs Robinson, names ranged from Joan Crawford, Lauren Bacall, Audrey Hepburn, Rita Hayworth and Judy Garland, whilst for Benjamin, Robert Redford, Warren Beatty, Harrison Ford, Robert Duvall and Jack Nicholson were considered. The buck of names didnâ??t stop there as Faye Dunaway, Shirley MacLaine, Sally Field and Jane Fonda were considered for Elaine. The shock is that some of these actors rejected the role, and some were so desperate to play a part that Ava Gardner called Nichols asking about the film. This goes to show how intriguing the characters were to Hollywood, and although some of the final choices are debatable, the characters are what remain fantastic.
 
The Graduate is creatively endowed as it drifts away from the notion of a coming-of-age story, thanks to its storylineâ??s cleverness in making adulthood such a fun and exciting lifestyle where the only worry seems to be finding a woman to love. Just like Benjamin is drifting through life not knowing exactly what he is meant to be doing, the camera almost doesnâ??t seem to know what to be doing, as it never interferes with the proceedings; it remains subjective and drifts ever so slowly through scenes. This works a treat as it amplifies the foreboding eroticism in order to intensify your fantasies, but this can also make The Graduate sort of undergraduate in intelligence, as it works to satisfy the story not the audienceâ??s interest. The Graduate can seriously be slow paced as Simon & Garfunkelâ??s hypnotic soundtrack including songs such as â??The Sound of Silenceâ?? provides a deliberate sluggishness to represent the unravelling of Benjaminâ??s purposeless life. But this doesnâ??t put you off as this coming-of-age-through-sexual-adventures saga is just too intriguing. Hollywood was also facing restrictions as to what can possibly be shown on film in 1967, but The Graduate almost matured cinema as it did Benjamin.
 
The Academy Awards took this film seriously, proving again it is not a comedy, as it, despite winning only for Best Director, was nominated for Best Picture and three acting categories. It baffles me as to why Anne Bancroft did not win, but then again Katharine Hepburn, who won, is the most heavily awarded actor ever.
 
The Verdict:
 
A salacious adventure that has melodramatically marked its place in cinematic history, for its coming-of-age story remains so effective almost half a century later. And that is predominantly Mrs Robinsonâ??s doing.
 
â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??        8/10

Lessons on love.  So this is about a college graduate (Dustin Hoffman) who comes home, only to find his longtime neighbor, Mrs. Robinson (Anne Bancroft), vying for his affection.  When she forbids him from seeing her daughter (Katharine Ross), it sets the scene for a whole lot of jilted drama.  Some time has passed since the last time I had the opportunity to watch the hilarity that is The Graduate; it's a film that I have nothing but fond memories for, but for whatever reason, it never managed to find a way into my rotation of movies I rewatch on a regular basis.  As always, working my way through the list of 1,001 Movies You Must See Before You Die gives me a great excuse to revist the classics I otherwise wouldn't.  Regardless if you've ever had an affair with an older married woman, what makes The Graduate work is how relatable it is.  This is also what makes it so funny as well, and watching Hoffman get entangled in this tricky predicament leads to big laughs.  He's at the age where he can be confused about what he wants, and it is easy to see why he gets overwhelmed like he does, especially when there is a manipulative man-eater that has him in her sights.  It's his age and demeanor that make you buy into his character; with where he's at, there is an uncertainty about the future, and everybody wants to give him advice for this transition period of his life.  Given that these are close family friends doling it out, and given that he's a polite young man, he doesn't have really much of a choice here, other than to nod his head and listen.  For a comedy, The Graduate has some excellent direction, which is something that is rare to see within the genre.  It's so good that it even took home an Oscar for it.  On top of the direction and the wonderful performances (Mrs. Robinson is one of the all-time great tragic characters), everything is tied together by one of the most iconic soundtracks of all time, courtesy of Mr. Paul Simon and Mr. Art Garfunkel.  Every element about this is top notch, but I do have one qualm about it that holds it back from being a perfect film, for me at least: it hits a drag point right before the big finish.  It's only for a 10 minute period or so, and I think it is just because the play a reprise for the same song three times in a row, but I did notice it.  Still, the wedding finale more than makes up for it, and this is considered to be a classic for a reason.

For years, I've seen The Graduate toted as a defining entry in film history. Obviously, I'm decades removed from experiencing its original effect. Now, looking back, I can't quite understand why the movie is so esteemed. Granted, it's a terrifically acted movie (in large part), the production design is stellar, and the dialogue is charming.

It all starts out well enough. There's a funny but pervasively melancholy tone. We're introduced to the premise: a recent (and depressed) college graduate starts an affair with his father's business partner's wife. We come to learn more about both Benjamin and Mrs. Robinson. There's a fantastic scene where the two talk, actually talk, for the first time. It's still a pretty twisted story, but it could have led to an interesting tale of two people figuring out their complicated situations.

But that all comes grinding to a halt when Mrs. Robinson's daughter, Elaine, enters the picture. Now, this isn't a bad development - it actually opens another interesting avenue of story possibilities. And for one scene there, Ben and Elaine's first date, things are working nicely. But from that point forward, the movie becomes unbelievably fake. I wasn't buying a relationship based off one date, I wasn't buying Mrs. Robinson turning into a one-dimensional psychotic, I wasn't buying Ben turning into a mildly disturbing stalker, and I wasn't buying Elaine losing all semblance of personality.

And then the movie ends. Ben makes a definitive decision for the first time in his life. He is escaping with Elaine. But as the two make their retreat on the bus, looks of disappointment cross their faces. Given how off the rails the movie went, this is probably the best ending imaginable. It keeps things really introspective. In the subtlest of ways, it's not quite the happy ending we've been conditioned to expect.

The acting by Dustin Hoffman and Anne Banecroft is truly terrific! Hoffman's line delivery is the most impressive thing about the movie. And while Ben isn't honestly that interesting of a character, Hoffman make him likable, at very least. The relationship between Ben and Mrs. Robinson isn't as weird as it could be. In actuality, Hoffman was only six years younger than Banecroft at the time if filming. On that, Banecroft offers up some fantastic acting of her own. The scene where she discusses her personal past with Benjamin is truly outstanding stuff. But unfortunately, her character is tossed to the side without sufficient exploration. In her place, Katharine Ross flatlines through the movie as Elaine. The film fails to build up a compelling relationship between Ben and Elaine, and in turn, the latter character ultimately detracts from the story.

On an unrelated note, the songs by Simon & Garfunkel work wonders. They understand the movie implicitly and they enhance every scene they accompany.

The Graduate has its pros (wonderful acting, direction, production, music, etc), but it's not without a healthy list of flaws (extremely disappointing second half, complete disregard for a main character, etc). So, given its reputation, I would definitely attest that The Graduate is overrated. The more you think about it, the more it falls apart. The ending isn't bad, but the journey from the middle of the movie to the ending certainly is. Still, as an important piece of film history, and as half of a really good movie, there's enough interesting stuff here to warrant a muted but positive reaction.

I understand the social commentary of The Graduate, and I can even relate to Ben's state of confusion after graduating college, but I can't say that the events following are appropriate enough given the context.

This film's biggest mistake isn't a mistake really at all. It is the fact that it's extremely dated. Perhaps The Graduate is historically significant, but it just doesn't hold up well at all. While deeply analyzing this film you can't deny that it's pretty smart, but that analysis must only come after understanding the perspective of the times--that is, the generation gap and the confusion of growing up in the '60s. And it's even unsure as to whether that acuity is intentional or not. The Graduate may have been relevant and sensible in 1967, but in this day and age it doesn't seem so. 

Another fault, which is a bit more tangible, lies within the characters. Their rationales don't make much sense. The film is made up of a cacophony of decisions that should be labeled as farce, but are taken way too seriously to even be considered as such. Elaine has to be the most annoying character. While she isn't a terrible person, it doesn't make any sense why she's in love with Ben and why she's so understanding towards him after thinking that he raped her mother. And apparently Ben and Elaine are in love with each other after one date--and not even a very good one at that. There is no affable character in this entire film. They all make you feel uncomfortable. And I have a hard time enjoying a film that gives me nobody to like or sympathize with.

This is an example of a movie that isn't a sum of its parts. There are many good scenes, but together they don't add up to an enjoyable experience. It doesn't feel like a story so much as a series of events that don't fit together seamlessly. Although stylistically even, the tone seems to be unset. 

There just simply isn't any redeeming value to this film whatsoever, and I can't say that I like it. Not to mention, he keeps driving on the Bay Bridge for no reason.

I just got done reading this book AND its screenplay for class, so finally it was time to see the movie itself. And...it's obviously much superior to the book, for a variety of reasons.

The book had virtually no imagery, no description, and pretty much no actual characterization going on. The reader was never actually aware of anyone's feelings except through dialogue. In movie form, we're able to see their expressions, and seeing it acted out makes it so much more interesting. I have to highly commend the acting - both Mrs. Robinson and (especially) Benjamin could be deeply unlikable characters, as they are in the book, but their actors give them depth, and, in Hoffman's case, an easy likability that makes it easier to ignore his many flaws and overall creepy attitude.

Also, the movie is way funnier. There are some lines that I read in the book/screenplay that I simply didn't recognize as funny then, but are borderline hilarious when watched on the screen. Hoffman's physicality was perfect for the role. Again, I have to stress that I hated his character in the book, and in the book the only character I found myself rooting for was Mr. Robinson. In the movie, though, it's easier to like him. Also: stylish directing, great editing, a good soundtrack, and nice cinematography all contribute to making the movie more enjoyable.

There are still some flaws. Like I said, Ben is pretty creepy at some points, and it's pretty ridiculous that he and Elaine are acting like they fell in love when they technically went on, what, one date? At least we got to see more of the date than in the book, and Katharine Ross's beauty makes his love for her a little easier to believe, but it's still hard to get TOO invested in that relationship without having seen much of it at all. Still, by the time Benjamin arrived at the wedding at the end, I was strangely invested, and as they ran out of the church together, Benjamin waving a cross around, I couldn't help but get caught up in the laughs and the thrills and root for them. This movie might have some of the same flaws the book did, but it works a hell of a lot better on screen with a great team of filmmakers.

You can't get more iconic than this. The Graduate is flawlessly written, deftly acted, and superbly touches us with its unconventionality and ultimate power. It captures the era of the 60s, yet is also profoundly timely. Hoffman's angst is relatable for every young adult watching the film, and the nostalgia and shallowness of American suburbia is also quite relatable to anyone who has spent at least a year living in the suburbs. Anne Bancroft is exceptional and ruthless as Mrs. Robinson, making for an unforgettable performance. The film's aura--the iconic soundtrack and iconic cinematographic choices--is captivating. Ultimately The Graduate is more than a funny, nostalgic movie: it is triumphant. It is a triumph of the human mind and the human spirit.

By the direction the film went by, it's indirectly a coming-of-age film that was frequently labeled under. The coming-of-age part is a college graduate (Dustin Hoffman) doesn't know where to go in his life after graduating. The indirect part is the graduate's life gets into a peculiar direction where he was put under a spell and foolishly gets into an affair with a characteristically-lacked woman, who developed into a villainy of a sexual predator/witch to torture the graduate's life in that direction. The cause of that developing turn is when her daughter - with an opposite behavior of nice and an angel who can misunderstood things - gets into the picture and gave the graduate's more comfort in his life when he fell in love with the right girl. The direct and indirect ways blend in when he has to go against the forces of evil that was caused and infected by the woman's actions so he can show her daughter how much he loves her.

The direction started calmly, until the affair tensed it and exploded with a satisfying, uncompleted resolution that took a melodramatic scene to lead up to that moment. But the scene near to the end is a key moment of Dustin Hoffman's career when his character becomes a rebel with bravery to stop his love getting married to someone somewhat less than him.

I was stunned about how well this movie has aged. This movie has been made over forty years ago, and yet only one element of this film couldn't exist in our modern world: Elaine. Benjamin and Mr and Mrs Robinson could very well be characters from the 2010s, as could the dialogue, but sadly, Elaine was written clearly as a woman from the 1960s, and it shows horribly. Most women in college today would at least think about marrying a man who has slept with her mother and taken her to a strip show purely to mock her. Although this movie has more of an excuse to have a weak female character than, say, "The Breakfast Club", it still could have benefitted from further developing Elaine. However, aside from her, I enjoyed the rest of the characters, as well as Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft's marvelous performances; the cinematography was fantastic, with appropriate lighting and angles; I loved the tense editing, and do I even need to mention Simon and Garfunkel? This film gets four and a half stars because of it's stunning craft, interesting performances, mostly good story and character development, and having a Buck Henry cameo.
